natural problem: Find all real values of $t$ which satisfy \[\frac{t(2t-3)}{4t-2} \le 0.\]
natural solution: Let $f(t) = t(2t-3)/(4t-2).$ We make a sign table for each of the three factors on the left-hand side: \begin{tabular}{c|ccc|c} &$t$ &$2t-3$ &$4t-2$ &$f(t)$ \\ \hline$t<0$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$0<t<\frac{1}{2}$ &$+$&$-$&$-$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$\frac{1}{2}<t<\frac{3}{2}$ &$+$&$-$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$t>\frac{3}{2}$ &$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}Therefore, we have $f(t) < 0$ when $t < 0$ or $\tfrac12 < t < \tfrac32.$ Because the inequality is non-strict, we must also include the values of $t$ for which $f(t) = 0,$ which are $t=0$ and $t =\tfrac32.$ Putting all this together, we get that the set of solutions for $t$ is $\boxed{(-\infty, 0] \cup (\tfrac12, \tfrac32]}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "t * (2*t - 3) / (4*t - 2) \<le> 0"
shows  "t \<in> {-\<infinity>..0} \<union> {1/2..3/2}"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all real values of $t$ which satisfy \[\frac{t(2t-3)}{4t-2} \le 0.\] The final Answer is (-\infty, 0] \cup (\tfrac12, \tfrac32]
 ### Proof
 Let $f(t) = t(2t-3)/(4t-2).$ We make a sign table for each of the three factors on the left-hand side: \begin{tabular}{c|ccc|c} &$t$ &$2t-3$ &$4t-2$ &$f(t)$ \\ \hline$t<0$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$0<t<\frac{1}{2}$ &$+$&$-$&$-$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$\frac{1}{2}<t<\frac{3}{2}$ &$+$&$-$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$t>\frac{3}{2}$ &$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}Therefore, we have $f(t) < 0$ when $t < 0$ or $\tfrac12 < t < \tfrac32.$ Because the inequality is non-strict, we must also include the values of $t$ for which $f(t) = 0,$ which are $t=0$ and $t =\tfrac32.$ Putting all this together, we get that the set of solutions for $t$ is $\boxed{(-\infty, 0] \cup (\tfrac12, \tfrac32]}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "t * (2*t - 3) / (4*t - 2) \<le> 0"
shows  "t \<in> {-\<infinity>..0} \<union> {1/2..3/2}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: For what values of $t$ is the expression $\frac{t(2t - 3)}{4t - 2}$ non-positive? The solution is $t$ is either less than or equal to $0$ or $t$ is between $1/2$ and $3/2$, inclusive.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t :: real
assumes h0 : "t * (2 * t - 3) / (4 * t - 2) \<le> 0"
shows  "t \<le> 0 \<or> (t > 1/2 \<and> t \<le> 3/2)"
